tossups.question: Shorting a circuit containing one type of this device generates a randomly-directed spontaneous ground state current. An LC circuit in which a series of these devices replaces the inductor forms a low-noise tunable device known as this device’s parametric amplifier. A circuit containing a series of these devices establishes the standard for one volt. It is represented in circuit diagrams by an x, and typical I-V diagrams of them have a (*) vertical line on the y-axis superimposed on a diagonal curve where breakdown occurs. Their phase evolution equation sets the time derivative of phase to be “2, times electric charge, times voltage over h-bar.” Circuits containing these devices can be tuned by varying the external magnetic flux. Two of them in parallel can measure small magnetic fields in a device known as a SQUID. For 10 points, name these devices consisting of two superconductors separated by a non-superconductor.
tossups.answer: Josephson junctions [or pi Josephson junctions; accept Josephson parametric amplifiers; prompt on JJs] <Science - Physics>
tossups.answer_formatted: Josephson junctions <Science - Physics> [or pi Josephson junctions; accept Josephson parametric amplifiers; prompt on JJs]

tossups.question: Description acceptable. The Diary of Joseph Naples recounts the author’s time in this profession, which enriched Jack Hartnett and Ben Crouch before rumors about it ruined their fortunes. A prominent practitioner of this profession had his skeleton articulated and displayed at Edinburgh Medical School after his hanging. Levi Parmley, the inventor of dental floss, may have done extensive business with a mysterious member of this profession known as Butler, who followed Wellington’s (*) armies in the Peninsular War. A crackdown on this profession ensued after the murder of 16 people in Scotland by two of its members, William Burke and William Hare. Articles in the Terrific Register likely inspired Charles Dickens to portray this profession with the character of Jerry Cruncher in A Tale of Two Cities. For 10 points, name this profession that supplied scientific researchers like Andreas Vesalius, whose members often lurked around cemeteries.
tossups.answer: resurrection men [or grave robbers, accept descriptive answers relating to people who sold corpses or body parts or teeth; accept resurrectionists, burkers or burking] <History - European>
tossups.answer_formatted: resurrection men <History - European> [or grave robbers, accept descriptive answers relating to people who sold corpses or body parts or teeth; accept resurrectionists, burkers or burking]
acceptable: grave robbers, accept descriptive answers relating to people who sold corpses

tossups.question: The protagonist of a novel with this title often dreams of a king who asks his daughter’s suitors the riddle “What is the greatest tribute and homage a man can give to the woman he loves?” That novel with this title, which contrasts lengthy descriptions of the Cathedral of Gerona’s Tapestry of the Creation with the travels of Ecks, was written by Cristina Peri Rossi. The evil Spanish twins Ric and Rac steal La Condesa’s pearls in another novel with this title, which climaxes with a (*) drunken party where Mrs. Treadwell smashes Denny’s face with her shoe. A medieval poem with this title invented the vulgar Saint Grobian and the fictional paradise of Narragonia. A 1962 novel with this title is often read as an allegory for the rise of Nazism, and depicts the journey of the German ship Vera from Mexico to Europe. For 10 points, identify this shared title of a satire by Sebastian Brant and the only novel of Katharine Anne Porter.
tossups.answer: The Ship of Fools [or La nave de los locos; or Das Narrenschiff; or Stultifera Navis] <Literature - European>
tossups.answer_formatted: The Ship of Fools <Literature - European> [or La nave de los locos; or Das Narrenschiff; or Stultifera Navis]

tossups.question: In one appearance, after claiming that he knows about thugs because he’s researched them, this character listens to his friend tell a story in which he learns that his uncle was transformed into a knife. In one story, this character produces a dollar bill to convince another character that they are facing the Charles River, rather than the Rhône. This character unsuccessfully examines one of Justus Perthes’ atlases for reference to a region whose (*) heresiarch once declared that “mirrors and copulation are abominable.” Later, following the death of Herbert Ashe, this character inherits the eleventh volume of a certain encyclopedia. In another appearance, this character talks to a portrait of Beatriz Elena Viterbo before her brother Carlos comes in and tells him how to use the Aleph. For 10 points, name this character who shares his name with the author of Dreamtigers.
tossups.answer: Jorge Luis Borges [accept either] <Literature - Other/World>
tossups.answer_formatted: Jorge Luis Borges <Literature - Other/World> [accept either]

tossups.question: A parody of this film contains the recurring joke of an unattended baby getting stuck in dangerous places due to its mother’s desire to become a pop star. This film’s screenwriter later wrote a screenplay about its lead actor’s later inability to find work outside of bit parts. In a 1989 parody, frequent commercial breaks and a power outage disrupt a director’s reinterpretation of this film. At the end of this film, the dynamic between the two protagonists is inverted, a move foreshadowed by an early scene in which one of them imitates the other’s (*) morning routine. An anti-commercialist parody of this film is the best-known work of comedian Maurizio Nichetti [nee-KEH tee]. A restaurant scene in this film cuts between a rich family and the central father-son duo. At the start of this film, Maria pawns her bedsheets to help her husband get a job posting ads. For 10 points, name this film by Vittorio de Sica.
tossups.answer: Bicycle Thieves [or Ladri di biciclette; accept The Bicycle Thief] <Arts - Audiovisual, Other>
tossups.answer_formatted: Bicycle Thieves <Arts - Audiovisual, Other> [or Ladri di biciclette; accept The Bicycle Thief]

tossups.question: Two researchers who studied this practice among agoraphobics argued that it often involves the technique of “transposition.” The anthropologist Michael Jackson’s work among refugees in New Zealand was the basis for a book titled for the “politics” of this practice. “Embeddedness,” “linearity,” and “moral stance” are three of the five dimensions of this practice in everyday life, according to Elinor (*) Ochs and Lisa Capps. One essay attributes the spread of this practice to the contact between craftsmen and journeymen, and argues that a symptom of its decline was the rise of the novel, which unlike this practice is “dependent on the book.” In that essay, which is titled for practitioner of this art, Walter Benjamin analyzed the works of Nikolai Leskov. For 10 points, name this practice, an example of which is the oral recounting of a folktale.
tossups.answer: storytelling [accept any answer that involves the telling of stories, tales, or narratives; accept oral literature until “oral”; accept The Politics of Storytelling and “The Storyteller”] <Social Science>
tossups.answer_formatted: storytelling <Social Science> [accept any answer that involves the telling of stories, tales, or narratives; accept oral literature until “oral; accept The Politics of Storytelling or The Storyteller]
acceptable: any answer that involves the telling of stories, tales,

tossups.question: Tombs from this kingdom are frequently topped with a double stairway motif symbolizing routes to heaven. Diodorus Siculus claimed that this kingdom had a law requiring people who built vineyards or houses to be put to death. This kingdom’s ruler Obodas built a temple to commemorate his victory over Alexander Janneus, the king of a local rival that had captured one of its major ports. This kingdom levied trade duties from forts like Mamshit and Avdat. This kingdom used the port of Leuke Kome for sea trade, and was ruled by several kings named (*) Aretas. A long canyon called the Siq is the only way to access a city built by this kingdom, which features a “treasury” building this kingdom funded from its location on an “incense route” extending north from Yemen. For 10 points, name this kingdom ruled from Petra, a buffer state between the Antigonids and Ptolemaic Egypt that is located mostly in modern Jordan.
tossups.answer: Nabataean Kingdom <History - Mediterranean+>
tossups.answer_formatted: Nabataean Kingdom <History - Mediterranean+>

tossups.question: The first male Londoner to carry an umbrella, Jonas Hanway, published a four hundred page diatribe against this resource for being a threat to English masculinity. Erika Rappaport’s 2018 history on how this resource “shaped the modern world” describes how the English had a single name for it prior to the publication of clergyman John Ovington’s Voyage to Surat in 1689. Smugglers from the notorious Hawkhurst gang quilted this resource under their coats to avoid detection. The Scotsman Robert (*) Fortune infamously stole the source of this good while employed by the British East India Company. After purchasing this good on credit in Canton, British merchants would balance their debts by selling opium and smuggling it back to China. Nearly every word for this good worldwide falls into one of three different groups, all of which trace back to Chinese. For 10 points, name this good, crates of which were destroyed in 1773 in Boston Harbor.
tossups.answer: tea <Modern World>
tossups.answer_formatted: tea <Modern World>

tossups.question: In contrast to alkyl sulfoxides, allylic sulfoxides undergo this reaction rapidly at moderate temperatures via a sulfenate ester intermediate that can be trapped by a nucleophile like tri·methoxy·phosphine. In peptide synthesis, hydroxy·benzo·triazoles HOBt and HOAt are used to form an activated ester that quickly couples to the next amino acid without allowing this reaction. This process is the consequence of another process that produces a Q-branch on the rovibrational spectra of (*) pyramidal compounds; that other process occurs via quantum tunneling. Enolate formation causes this process to occur but isolated to the alpha-carbon atom. This process occurs in SN1 but not in SN2 since the carbocation in SN1 is planar, and it occurs in the aforementioned nitrogen inversion. This process is the opposite of chiral resolution. For 10 points, name this process that destroys stereochemical information, forming an even mix of enantiomers.
tossups.answer: racemization [accept epimerization since all of the clues only refer to one chiral center; accept forming a racemic mixture or forming an optically inactive mixture; accept destroying stereochemical information before it is stated] <Science - Chemistry>
tossups.answer_formatted: racemization <Science - Chemistry> [accept epimerization since all of the clues only refer to one chiral center; accept forming a racemic mixture or forming an optically inactive mixture; accept destroying stereochemical information before it is stated]

tossups.question: One of these documents, part of a published collection curated by Harold Syrett, was subjected to hyperspectral analysis in 2018 to reveal that crossed-out text contained a racy section about “unrestrained intercourses.” The last of these documents to be produced expresses regret that its author could not “avoid the interview” necessitated after Charles Cooper wrote an account of a dinner party speech given by the author. The recipient of these documents laments that “your enemy whispers so you have to scream” before noting “I know about whispers” in a (*) rearrangement of a piece whose original version explains that these documents “built palaces out of paragraphs” and “flooded my senses.” That track is sung during the destruction of many of these documents after the recipient declares “the world has no place in our bed / they don’t get to know what I said,” and occurs after the author of these documents admits his affair with Maria Reynolds. The song “Burn” concerns the destruction of—for 10 points—what documents written by the first Treasury Secretary to Eliza Schuyler?
tossups.answer: Alexander Hamilton’s Love Letters to his wife [or to Elizabeth Schuyler before mentioned; accept equivalents; answer must supply sender and recipient; prompt on answers like “writings by Hamilton” with “what kind of writings?”, and on answers of “letters by Hamilton” with “to whom?”] <Mythology and Other>
tossups.answer_formatted: Alexander Hamilton’s Love Letters to his wife <Mythology and Other> [or to Elizabeth Schuyler before mentioned; accept equivalents; answer must supply sender and recipient; prompt on answers like “writings by Hamilton” with “what kind of writings?”, or on answers of “letters by Hamilton” with “to whom?]

tossups.question: In 1805, a baker in this city knocked some ash from his pipe, which ignited a pile of hay, starting a conflagration that destroyed this city and is referenced in the Latin motto on its flag, which was penned by Gabriel Richard. Following the fire, a design based on radial avenues and modeled after L’Enfant’s plan for Washington D.C. was made for this city by Augustus Woodward. Legendarily, the founder of this city incurred misfortunes after using a cane to strike an impish red creature named (*) “Nain Rouge,” who is honored yearly by a spring festival here. The Battle of Bloody Run was an unsuccessful attempt to break an assault on this city. William Hull was sentenced to death after surrendering this city to the British during the War of 1812. In 1701, Fort Pontchartrain was founded on the west bank of this city’s namesake river by Antoine de la Mothe Cadillac. In 1763, Pontiac unsuccessfully besieged—for 10 points—what Midwestern city that later became the center of the automobile industry?
tossups.answer: Detroit <History - American>
tossups.answer_formatted: Detroit <History - American>

tossups.question: An epic poem inspired by this author’s ideas ends with a “shrouded figure” showing the speaker burning cities and starving children in a section called “The Leading of Sorrow.” That epic poem, whose name evokes one of this author’s books, was written by Mathilde Blind. Gillian Beer analyzed the impact of this author on George Eliot and Thomas Hardy in a book about this author’s “plots.” In his autobiography, he lamented “now for many years I cannot endure to read a line of poetry.” The final paragraph of a book by this author features an extended metaphor about a (*) “tangled bank.” Samuel Butler apologized to this author for seeming to parody his ideas in three chapters of Erewhon about the danger of machines attaining consciousness. Supporters of this author frequently quoted Tennyson’s line “Nature, red in tooth and claw.” For 10 points, name this scientist who upended Victorian notions of nature with his theory of evolution.
tossups.answer: Charles (Robert) Darwin (The Mathilde Blind poem is The Ascent of Man.) <Literature - British>
tossups.answer_formatted: Charles Darwin (The Mathilde Blind poem is The Ascent of Man.) <Literature - British>
acceptable: Charles Darwin (The Mathilde Blind poem is The Ascent of Man.) <Literature - British>

tossups.question: Paul Koebe showed that the sum over n of “n times z-to-the-n” maximally satisfies a conjecture about mappings from this set. This set is the codomain in a theorem whose proof begins by writing a function as “z minus z-naught, all times e-to-the g-of-z” and then determining the real part of “g-of-z.” The distance metric “inverse-tanh [tanch] of quantity: norm of z-sub-1 minus z-sub-2, all over one minus z-sub-1-bar, z-sub-2” is non-decreasing under automorphisms of this set by the Schwarz–Pick lemma. Bieberbach’s conjecture concerns the norms of the coefficients of functions called schlicht that are defined on this set. Like the upper (*) half-plane, it can be used to model hyperbolic space with the Klein or Poincaré metrics. On the boundary of this set, the function “one over one minus norm-of-z” is non-holomorphic. Any simply connected open subset of the complex plane is biholomorphic to this set by the Riemann mapping theorem. For 10 points, name this set of all points with norm less than 1.
tossups.answer: open unit disk [do not accept or prompt on other shapes, e.g. “unit sphere” or “unit circle”; do not accept or prompt on partial answer] <Science - Other>
tossups.answer_formatted: open unit disk <Science - Other> [do not accept or prompt on "other shapes, e.g. “unit sphere" or "unit circle"; do not accept or prompt on partial answer]

tossups.question: A tondo on the east side of the Arch of Constantine may have inspired a torch-bearing putto in this painting, who has been identified as Phosphorus. Along with Annibale Caracci’s Loves of the Gods, which was painted 20 years earlier, this painting is a classic example of a quadro riportato, i.e. a fresco meant to resemble a framed easel painting. The collection of this painting’s patron housed a second-century Roman marble relief of “dancers” that inspired the billowing robes and joined hands of the Hours who dance around this painting’s central figure. This ceiling fresco was painted for a garden house, or (*) Casino, adjoining the Palazzo Pallavicini-Rospigliosi [pah-lah-vah-CHEE-nee roh-spee-LYOH-see] of Cardinal Scipione Borghese. For 10 points, name this masterpiece of Guido Reni, which depicts a chariot procession of Apollo led by the goddess of dawn.
tossups.answer: L’Aurora [accept anything mentioning Aurora; accept answers mentioning dawn until that’s mentioned] <Arts - Visual>
tossups.answer_formatted: L’Aurora <Arts - Visual> [accept anything mentioning Aurora; accept answers mentioning dawn until that’s mentioned]

tossups.question: In a book titled for a member of this group, a later philosopher claimed that “in essential history the beginning comes last.” That book claims that the same member of this group “thinks [fate] as the basic feature of presencing.” A member of this group divides the “acquisitive” and “productive” arts before defining a certain profession as “the imitative kind of dissembling part of the art of opinion.” That unnamed character from this group takes the role of Socrates in the (*) Sophist. A member of this group argues against the forms with the “third man” argument in a Platonic dialogue. That founder of this school divided his only surviving work into the “way of opinion” and “way of truth.” For 10 points, name this Pre-Socratic school whose members included Parmenides, named for the hometown of a Zeno who generated paradoxes about motion.
tossups.answer: Eleatic school [or Eleans] <Philosophy>
tossups.answer_formatted: Eleatic school <Philosophy> [or Eleans]

tossups.question: Mixed-gender street gangs including the “Buffalo Bills” and the “Yankees” were prevalent in this colony’s capital in the 1950s. A rivalry in this colony between the Polar and Primus brands of beer led Polar to hire a man who would later become its first post-independence leader as a salesman. The phrase “before independence = after independence” was written on a chalkboard in front of mutinous troops in this country, where a type of rumba called soukous developed after the introduction of Cuban records. This colony supplied the majority of the (*) Manhattan Project’s uranium. Emile Jansenns led a paramilitary force in this colony, which used forced labor to build railroads to cities such as Elisabethville. A political party led by Joseph Kasa-vubu dominated this colony’s pre-independence politics, and Patrice Lumumba advocated for this colony’s independence. For 10 points, name this central African colony formed after a “Free State” personally owned by Leopold II was dissolved.
tossups.answer: Belgian Congo [prompt on Democratic Republic of the Congo; do not accept or prompt on “Congo Free State”] <History - Other/World>
tossups.answer_formatted: Belgian Congo <History - Other/World> [prompt on Democratic Republic of the Congo; do not accept or prompt on "Congo Free State"]

tossups.question: Description acceptable. This person notes a discrepancy between two different versions of the Pentateuch concerning a mountain’s location. A detail from this person’s story is often interpreted as a reference to the five tribes living in the town of Sychar. This person is told that God must be worshipped “in spirit and in truth” and that “salvation is of the Jews,” although this person is told that “Ye worship ye know not what.” The story involving this person seems to be modelled on Jacob’s first encounter with (*) Rachel, and takes place at a location named for Jacob. This unnamed character, who is amazed when Christ tells her that she’s had five husbands, asks Jesus if he’s greater than Jacob. For 10 points, identify this Samaritan woman in the fourth chapter of John who is told of the Living Water after Jesus asks her for a drink.
tossups.answer: Samaritan woman at the well [prompt on partial answer; accept Photine, Photini, or Photina] <Religion>
tossups.answer_formatted: Samaritan woman at the well <Religion> [prompt on partial answer; accept Photine, Photini, or Photina]

tossups.question: This book incorporates its author’s responses to a questionnaire distributed by the Partisan Review into an “intermission” section titled “Conversation in the Lobby.” This book’s preamble, which encourages the reader to turn a record player up as loud as possible and blast Beethoven’s Seventh into their ear, describes its goal as contriving techniques that are able to “recognize the stature of a portion of unimagined existence.” This book features a multi-page description of a fireplace fringed with tissue paper that its author terms “the altar,” which is included in a section titled (*) “Shelter.” Expanded into a book after Fortune magazine declined to publish the article that formed its basis, it features three sections set on the porches of the pseudonymous Woods, Ricketts, and Gudger families. Dozens of photographs documenting the lives of Alabama sharecroppers were included in—for 10 points—what collaboration between Walker Evans and James Agee?
tossups.answer: Let Us Now Praise Famous Men <Literature - American>
tossups.answer_formatted: Let Us Now Praise Famous Men <Literature - American>
acceptable: Let Us Now Praise Famous Men <Literature - American>
Let Us Now Praise Famous Men <Literature - American>

tossups.question: While on a short break from the Art Ensemble of Chicago in 1977, Lester Bowie played as a sideman on four of this musician’s albums. On a 1971 live album, this musician was accompanied by both longtime collaborator Tony Allen and Cream drummer Ginger Baker, who brought this musician on for the album Stratavarious. This musician frequently included two baritone saxophones in his band, and he made half-hour long songs divided into an instrumental Part 1 and a vocal Part 2 on albums like (*) I.T.T. and Confusion. This musician attacked political and military corruption in songs like “Zombie” and “Expensive Shit.” Producer Brian Eno was inspired by this musician to use polyrhythmic layers of drumming on the album Remain in Light. Highlife, jazz, and funk were fused to create Afrobeat by—for 10 points—what Nigerian musician?
tossups.answer: Fela (Anikulapo) Kuti [or Fela Ransome Kuti] <Arts - Auditory>
tossups.answer_formatted: Fela Kuti <Arts - Auditory> [or Fela Ransome Kuti]

tossups.question: The output of one of these systems is dependent on a protein rearranging its tertiary structure to form a “fold-switched” state. The central protein of one system of this type has a characteristic “double doughnut” shape consisting of the CI and CII rings. Nakajima et al. showed in 2005 that the simplest of these systems had normal function in vitro and did not function via transcription-translation feedback; that system of this type, found in cyanobacteria, operates via modulation of the auto·phosphatase/auto·kinase activity of KaiC. Neurospora crassa’s (*) frq gene codes for a protein in one of these systems. In mammals, the most common of these systems is formed from a heterodimer between two members of the bHLH-PAS family of transcription factors. For their discovery of the PER/TIM loop and other components of this type of system in fruit flies, Hall, Rosbash, and Young were awarded the 2017 Nobel Prize in Medicine. For 10 points, name these systems that entrain to light levels, thereby generating 24-hour rhythms in organisms.

bonuses.leadin: Area X, the LMAN, and the HVC have all been shown to be key neural areas for this process. For 10 points each:
answers: avian vocal learning [or avian song learning; accept answers mentioning “birds” instead of “avian”; prompt on partial answers; do not accept or prompt on answers about “song production”]
prefrontal cortex [or PFC; accept anterior frontal lobe; prompt on frontal lobe]
thalamus [do not accept or prompt on “hypothalamus”] <Science - Biology>
parts: Name this process that relies on repeated comparison between the BOS and the stored template. Organisms undergoing this process go through “sub” and “plastic” phases before reaching the final, or “crystallized,” state.

The HVC in the nidopallium is the portion of the avian brain that is responsible for the learning and production of bird song. The nidopallium is analogous to this foremost portion of the human brain, which is responsible for executive function.

The prefrontal cortex is the projection zone of the medial dorsal nucleus of this structure, which is responsible for controlling the flow of incoming sensory information to the cortex. It’s the topmost part of the diencephalon.
answers_formatted: avian vocal learning [or avian song learning; accept answers mentioning “birds” instead of “avian; prompt on partial answers; do not accept or prompt on "answers about “song production"]
prefrontal cortex [or PFC; accept anterior frontal lobe; prompt on frontal lobe]
thalamus <Science - Biology> [do not accept or prompt on "hypothalamus"]

bonuses.leadin: This dancer was given her own talk show after a viral video in which she attacked Chinese reality TV for exploiting contestants’ pain. For 10 points each:
answers: StarCraft player [or SC player; accept Brood War player ; accept StarCraft II player or SCII player; prompt on e-sports player or video gamer; do not accept or prompt on answers about “streaming”] <Mythology and Other>
parts: Name this host of the popular show “Dating China,” who was one of China’s foremost ballet dancers before retiring in 1995 and remains the foremost transgender Chinese celebrity.
Jin Xing wrote about having to give up dancing when her leg was paralyzed following gender confirmation surgery in a memoir named for this city on the Yangtze Delta, China’s largest.

Jin made her film debut in Resurrection of the Little Match Girl, which is like the Hans Christian Andersen story except it’s about a guy who gets sucked into an alternate dimension while desperately aspiring to this profession. This was the profession of sAviOr, who was banned from it for life after a 2010 scandal.
answers_formatted: StarCraft player <Mythology and Other> [or SC player; accept Brood War player; accept StarCraft II player or SCII player; prompt on e-sports player or video gamer; do not accept or prompt on "answers about “streaming"]

bonuses.leadin: Chad Harbach edited a collection examining the contemporary cultural divide in American literature between these programs and New York City. For 10 points each:
answers: MFA programs [prompt on creative writing programs by asking “What degree do these programs confer?”; accept Master of Fine Arts programs; accept masters in creative writing program]
parts: Name these typically two- or three-year graduate programs attended by aspiring American fiction writers. Many of these programs were founded to emulate the principles of the Iowa Writers’ Workshop.

This author critiqued the whiteness of MFA programs in his 2014 New Yorker article “MFA vs. POC.” In May 2018, Zinzi Clemmons publicly accused him of sexually harassing her at a workshop, prompting him to step down as chair of the Pulitzer Prize Board.

John Hawkes and Robert Coover were long-tenured instructors at this university’s creative writing program, which encourages experimental fiction and poetry. George Houston Bass founded this university’s Rites and Reason Theatre, one of the oldest black theatre workshops in the United States.
answers_formatted: MFA programs [prompt on creative writing programs by asking “What degree do these programs confer?; accept Master of Fine Arts programs; accept masters in creative writing program]

bonuses.leadin: In one story, this figure calls a man the “blind son of a blind man” after he falls into a pool of water. For 10 points each:
answers: Drāupadī [do not accept or prompt on “Drupada”; prompt on Panchalī or Yajñasenī]
parts: Name this figure who, according to another legend, washed her hair in her brother-in-law’s blood to avenge being humiliated in a game of dice.
In the Mahābhārata, Drāupadī is the wife of all five of these brothers, who include Arjuna and the hugely strong Bhima.

Drāupadī at first marries only Arjuna after he shoots a fish’s eye with an arrow at one of these ceremonies. Sita chooses Rama as her husband after he lifts and strings Shiva’s bow in one of these ceremonies.
answers_formatted: Drāupadī [do not accept or prompt on "Drupada"; prompt on Panchalī or Yajñasenī]

sieges [accept The History of the Siege of Lisbon or História do Cerco de Lisboa] <Literature - European>
parts: Name this novel, in which Mark-Alem attempts to protect his family from political persecution while being employed by the Bureau of Sleep to catalogue and interpret the title events.

The Palace of Dreams was banned by the this country’s Communist government. Its author, Ismail Kadare, is from this Balkan country, and depicted the aftermath of its invasion by Italy in his novel The General of the Dead Army.

In a Kadare novel whose English translation is titled for this kind of event, the engineer Saruxha creates giant destructive cannons. In a José Saramago novel, the proofreader Raimundo Silva rewrites the history of one of these events out of love for his boss Maria Sara.

acceptable: The History of the Siege of Lisbon

bonuses.leadin: This school of thought is named for the pseudonyms its creators adopted while creating it. For 10 points each,
parts: Name this school of leftist thought, expressed in essays such as “Every cook can govern,” which emphasized the primacy of the working class. It broke with the Socialist Workers’ Party over its interpretation of the Soviet Union as state-capitalist.

The founders of the tendency, C.L.R. James and Raya Dunayevskaya, opened a book by endorsing this man’s theory that revolution could not stop in Russia. This man’s followers formed the Fourth International after his exile.

C.L.R. James is most famous in academia for a history of the Haitian revolution titled for “Black” members of this group. In it, he claims that the French Revolution would be seen as a race war if these people were black.

bonuses.leadin: This artist’s Woman with Dog consists of a pink woman and a white dog made entirely of fake seashells. For 10 points each:
answers: roosters [accept Hahn/Cock or The Liver is the Cock’s Comb]
parts: Name this contemporary German artist primarily known for oversized sculptures of unsettling scenes. She’s best-known for Rat King, a circle of giant black polyester rats.

In 2013, Fritsch installed a giant blue one of these animals in Trafalgar Square. One of these animals partially titles a 1944 proto-Abstract Expressionist painting by the artist of Portrait of Master Bill.
Fritsch has often drawn comparisons to this sculpturist, since both often sculpt oddly colored, larger than life objects. This artist is best known for his kitschy “balloon dogs” sculptures.
answers_formatted: roosters [accept Hahn/Cock or The Liver is the Cock’s Comb]
acceptable: The Liver is the Cock’s Comb

bonuses.leadin: This method can be implemented using the python package CVX·OPT. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this process that solves optimization problems on functions of the form [read slowly] “x-transpose Q x, plus c-transpose x”, where Q is a positive semidefinite matrix.

The solution to this supervised learning model can be reduced to a quadratic programming problem. The “kernel” form of this supervised learning model has increased generalization error but can produce nonlinear decision boundaries, and its linear form provides a maximum-margin hyperplane as its solution.

One-class SVM models can be used to detect these “anomalous” data points that are often interpreted as due measurement error. Including these data points when formulating statistics skews the estimates of population means.

bonuses.leadin: In Act 5 of Henry IV, Part One, Falstaff claims that this concept cannot “take away the grief of a wound” before calling it “a mere scutcheon.” For 10 points each:
parts: Name this concept. Thomas Carew [“carey”] compared it to a giant that “keeps cowards out” in his poem “A Rapture,” which ends by asking why this “goblin” concept, “which the world adores, should make men atheists, and not women whores?”
This Cavalier poet declared “I could not love thee (Dear) so much / Lov’d I not honour more” at the end of his poem “To Lucasta, Going to the Wars.”

This crafty Shakespearean character asserts that “honour travels in a strait so narrow” in a speech beginning “Time hath, my lord, a wallet at his back.” In Act 1, Scene 3, he delivers a speech about the importance of social order which claims “Take but degree away, untune that string / And, hark, what discord follows!”

bonuses.leadin: As part of this campaign, the swamps around the trading colony Cho Lon were drained, allowing it to progress to a future national capital. For 10 points each:
answers: March to the South [or Nam tien; or Southward March; prompt on settling or colonizing South Vietnam; do not accept any answer indicating China doing things in Vietnam]
parts: Identify this process of internal colonization in which people of a certain ethnic group expanded out of the Red River valley, displacing indigenous peoples like the Cham.
The March to the South culminated under this dynasty’s ruler Minh Mang. This dynasty became Vietnam’s last after the abdication of Bao Dai.

Minh Mang’s efforts were in part designed to prevent the recurrence of uprisings like this one, named for the home district of three clan brothers who took advantage of a civil war between the Le and Mac Dynasties to rebel in the late eighteenth century.
answers_formatted: March to the South [or Nam tien; or Southward March; prompt on settling or colonizing South Vietnam; do not accept "any answer indicating China doing things in Vietnam"]

bonuses.leadin: A “Divertissement” is sandwiched between two very fast movements in a Francis Poulenc piece that adds a piano to this ensemble. For 10 points each:
answers: woodwind quintets [do not accept or prompt on “brass quintet”; prompt on partial answer]
parts: Name this ensemble for which Ligeti arranged his Six Bagatelles. A third-movement “praeludium” leads into the closing variations set in a 1922 work for this ensemble.
That wind quintet was written by this late Romantic and Modernist composer, who wrote six symphonies and oft-performed flute and clarinet concertos before his death in 1931.

Wind quintets often have the flutist sit out to perform this composer’s E-flat-major Quintet for piano and winds, which inspired a knock-off by Beethoven. He also wrote an A-major clarinet quintet for Anton Stadler.
answers_formatted: woodwind quintets [do not accept or prompt on "brass quintet"; prompt on partial answer]

bonuses.leadin: An exponent of 1.5 is sometimes used in these equations when examining modern situations. For 10 points each:
answers: B(asil) H(enry) Liddell Hart [prompt on partial answer] <History - Mediterranean+>
parts: Name this set of differential equations whose time model is continuous, as opposed to the discrete salvo combat model. Their linear form models melee combat and unaimed fire well, while their square law is closer to the aerial combat of World War One combat that the developer was first interested in.
Unmodified Lanchester theory best models attrition warfare, like that exemplified by this strategy, named for a Roman statesman who earned the name “delayer” for employing it.

World War I also inspired this other military theorist, whose landmark text Strategy advocates the Indirect Approach to warfare. John Merasheimer attacked this man for falsifying history to make it seem like Rommel was a disciple of this man’s theories.
answers_formatted: B H(enry) Liddell Hart <History - Mediterranean+> [prompt on partial answer]

bonuses.leadin: For 10 points each—answer the following about the Nazarov cyclization:
answers: cyclopentenones [prompt on less specific answers like ketone, alkene, or cyclopentene]
parts: This specific moiety is the product of the Nazarov cyclization, as well as the Pauson–Khand reaction. It undergoes a Diels–Alder reaction with Danishefsky’s diene as part of his synthesis of coriolin.

Whereas the Nazarov cyclization begins with a ketone, the Pauson–Khand reaction gets its carbonyl group from this molecule. This molecule is formed from incomplete combustion of hydrocarbons, and it binds to hemoglobin 150 times as strongly as oxygen.

Koenig et al. demonstrated in 2019 that the Nazarov cyclization does not require a metal catalyst; instead, one can use this element under mild conditions. This heteroatom has five covalent bonds in the Dess–Martin reagent.
answers_formatted: cyclopentenones [prompt on less specific answers like ketone, alkene, or cyclopentene]
promptable: less specific answers like ketone, alkene,

bonuses.leadin: This man’s paternity leave coincided with an attempt by his onetime partner, Íñigo Errejón, to take over his position. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this leader of a left-wing party that grew out of the 15-M Movement. This man’s decision not to run candidates directly but to mobilize party machinery led to the election of friendly mayors like Manuela Carmena.
Iglesias is the young Secretary-General of this political party, the largest in its country after the People’s Party, which formed in large part out of anger with austerity measures.

Podemos formed an electoral alliance with the Greens to contest regional elections in this Southernmost region of continental Spain, which ended up backfiring when the left lost a number of seats to the neofascist party, Vox. This region contains Córdoba and Granada.

bonuses.leadin: In a letter home, this man described shouting “Deutsch” and “Hitler” at Japanese soldiers in order to stop them from committing war crimes. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this German businessman who established a Safe Zone for Chinese civilians during the Rape of Nanking. Upon returning to Germany, he was imprisoned by the Gestapo for his efforts.

Rabe was partially selected because he was one of the few foreigners who remained in Nanjing after most were evacuated by this American gunboat, which would later be sunk by the Japanese in a 1937 incident that escalated tensions between the US and Japan before World War II.

The namesake of that later Panay was a captured Spanish gunboat whose crew once included John McCain Sr. and this man, who was appointed commander of Pacific naval forces after Pearl Harbor and won the Battle of Midway.

bonuses.leadin: This character was originally forced offstage during the number “Another National Anthem.” For 10 points each:
answers: Gilbert [accept Charles Gilbert, Jr. or W(illiam) S(chwenck) Gilbert]
parts: Name this character who sings about Charles Guiteau’s life while the latter sings “I am Going to the Lordy.”

The Balladeer narrates Stephen Sondheim’s Assassins, which was inspired by an earlier musical of the same name by a man with this surname. Another man with this surname wrote the libretto for Sir Arthur Sullivan’s H.M.S. Pinafore.

Possibly due to the timing and subject matter, this singer left Assassins out of his 2002 survey of Sondheim songs. This tenor originated the title role of Sunday in the Park with George, and he won a Tony for playing Ché Guevara in Evita.

bonuses.leadin: In this story, the Supreme Court cites a 1903 Oliver Wendell Holmes opinion in upholding the legality of a referendum that takes place on January 15. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this story in which the black conservative professor Gleason Golightly fails to convince the President’s cabinet not to sell African-Americans to aliens.
“The Space Traders” was included as the ninth chapter of this Harvard law professor’s book Faces at the Bottom of the Well. This man helped develop critical race theory.
Richard Delgado, another developer of CRT, is a law professor at the flagship university of this state, which saw the Montgomery Bus Boycott during the Civil Rights Movement.

bonuses.leadin: This theory in 2+1 dimensions predicts topological violations to the spin-statistics theory. For 10 points each:
answers: Chern–Simons theory [do not accept or prompt on “Chern–Simons form”]
parts: Name this doubly-eponymous quantum field theory that can be used to describe the fractional quantum Hall effect and calculate knot invariants. It gets its name because the action of the theory is equal to the integral of secondary characteristic classes that were also discovered by its two namesake mathematicians.

This American physicist created a conceptual proof of the spin-statistics theorem. He may be better known for his work on QED and in scattering theory, where he wrote down an equation equivalent to the Schrödinger equation along with Lippmann.
Schwinger’s formulation of QED allows computation of scattering amplitudes perturbatively using these diagrams, where wavy lines represent virtual photons.
answers_formatted: Chern–Simons theory [do not accept or prompt on "Chern–Simons form"]

bonuses.leadin: This book’s theories inspired Brian Friel’s play Translations. For 10 points each:
answers: tragedy (Yes, it’s called The Death of Tragedy.) <Literature - Other/World>
parts: Name this 1975 book, which contrasts the “monadist” view of language expressed by the Sapir–Whorf hypothesis with the “universal” view that all languages share the same underlying structure. It argues that every act of communication is an act of translation.

After Babel was written by this critic, who examined the way atrocities result in the “demolition” of language in his book Language and Silence. Jewish Nazi hunters find Adolf Hitler in the Amazon in his novella The Portage to San Cristobal of A.H.

Steiner argued that eighteenth-century rationalism killed this literary genre in a book named for its “death.” Aristotle’s Poetics recommends that heroes in this genre should possess a hamartia, or “mistake.”
metadata: Yes, it’s called The Death of Tragedy.

bonuses.leadin: This city housed a set of namesake “tables” that enumerated duties for sailors and captains, prices for hiring boats, and other aspects of maritime law widely used throughout port cities during the Middle Ages. For 10 points each:
answers: Amalfi [do not accept or prompt on “Malfi,” although yes, that is the Duchess thereof]
parts: Name this southern Italian city that was the seat of a duchy from 958 until 1137, when it was sacked by Pisa. Prior to her suspicious 1510 disappearance, Giovanna d’Aragona ruled this duchy for twelve years as regent for her infant son.

Amalfi may have been the birthplace of Flavio Gioia, a mariner who improved the design for this device by suspending its needle over a fleur-de-lis design. Innovations to this object led to increased navigation in the Mediterranean during the winter months.

Coins minted in the Duchy of Amalfi depict a precursor to this design, whose better-known version showing four converging arrowheads first appears in the historical record during the reign of Jean Parisot de la Valette.
answers_formatted: Amalfi [do not accept or prompt on "Malfi,” although yes, that is the Duchess thereof"]
rejectable: Malfi,” although yes, that is the Duchess thereof
